"One can't go out to give lessons without boots. And I'm tired of it."

"Don't fight with your way to make a living."

"They pay so little for lessons. What's the point of a few coins?" he replied, as if he were thinking out loud.

"And you want to get rich all at once?"

He looked at her in a strange way. 

"Yes, I want to get rich," he said firmly after a short pause.

"Don't rush, you're scaring me! Should I get you the bread or not?"

"As you wish."

"Oh, I almost forgot! A letter came for you yesterday while you were out."

"A letter? For me! From whom?"

"I can't say. I gave three kopecks of my own to the postman for it. Will you pay me back?"

"Then bring it to me, please, bring it!" Ras Kolnikov said, very excited. "Good God!"

A minute later, the letter was brought to him. It was from his mother, from the province of R——. He turned pale when he took it. It had been a long time since he got a letter, but another feeling suddenly hit him hard.

"Nastasya, leave me alone, for goodness' sake; here are your three kopecks, but please hurry and go!" 

The letter was shaking in his hand; he didn't want to open it.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov is anxious and excited about receiving a long-awaited letter from his mother, which stirs complex emotions within him.
